title: Friday, 18th December, 2015

11:11 am
BE

"Neck renewal cream"?

BE

Like, Frankenstein? What?

PM

A technology-advanced skincare that combines 3 innovations: 1/ the pearl technology which is an innovative encapsulation system that isolates the water phase from the oily phase. Therefore, it efficiently preserves the active ingredients. 2/ the bottle dispenser which is a unique packaging : once the pump is activated, the pearls liberate the serum without leaving any residue on the skin. 3/ the active ingredients : produced from an innovative and unique biotechnology process. The biotechnology allows to extract, from the heart of the cells, the active ingredients which are the most efficient for the skin. It also allows to reach the active ingredients of the most rare resources. Our skin represents a precious asset that time, fatigue and stress leave visibly altered. To counter this process, the skin requires efficient active ingredients. Youth Radiance Elixir, developed in exclusivity for Harrods, offers a radically new approach to skincare. Using Hyaluronic Acid, a powerful moisturizer; precious active ingredients obtained by biotechnology and a patented encapsulation system, Youth Radiance Elixir is made of translucent pearls, which, upon application, are transformed into a refine elixir easily absorbed texture. Skin is instantly smoothed, protected and lights up in a fresh glow.

PM

As the leaders of Global Research at RBC Capital Markets, we are pleased to present the Top 30 Global Ideas for 2016. The Top 30 is another example of the collective value of bringing together global thought leadership under one team and one firm.

PM

Pass the bucket when you're done

PM

Our global equity research analysts, informed by the views of our macro strategists across asset classes, sought to identify the most attractive investment ideas for the coming year. This report presents an investment summary of each of these recommendations, as well as the perspectives of our cross-asset macro strategists, who provide a broader context for the investing landscape.

11:19 am
PM

The composition of this year’s Top 30 Global Ideas reflects this macro outlook.

PM

Very sensible to my mind

PM

Three themes thread through this year’s list: Business Transformation, Cyclical Opportunities, and Higher Rates/Higher Financials.

11:20 am
PM

1) Business Transformation – ATD, ARMK, AVGO, DG (FP), DLTR, GOOGL, NWL, MPC, RDSB. Whether through M+A, productivity efforts, divestitures, and/or greater corporate transparency, we believe these management teams have taken their corporate fortunes into their own hands, and through a myriad of self-help initiatives, have unlocked meaningful value for shareholders by transforming their business models.

2) Cyclical Opportunities – AGU, AL, BAM, CBOE, CNR, CVE, ENB, HEXAB, INXN, IPL, RTN, WHR. Despite the lackluster environment for economically-sensitive stocks, we see opportunities to invest in these high-quality cyclical companies, where negative sentiment in their respective sectors has created an undue discount to their longer-term franchise value.

3) Higher Rates/Higher Financials – ALV (GY), IFC, LLOY, PNC, TD. A normalization of interest rate policies in the US and UK should benefit these core businesses as higher rates lead to a long-awaited improvement in NIMs.

BE

Hm. Okay. The first one has a dangling modifier and use of "a myriad of".

BE

Perhaps the "global thought leadership under one team and one firm" could do with an editor.

BE

BE

BE

Beyond the Casino CEO's exam grades in Greek and Latin as a teenager about half a century
ago, we have found nothing new yet in the report.

11:25 am
PM

bit of a smackdown

BE

Yup. And Bruno does, it has to be said, know what he's talking about.

BE

I can't paste at length, because Bernstein. But it goes through every bullet point then concludes .....

11:26 am
BE

The Muddy Waters report breaks no new ground on Casino at all. The complexity of Casino is well known and its leverage high and frequently discussed. However the company provides more data than probably any other business of that size through the 7 different publicly listed companies which enables investors to properly understand almost every single business stream in great detail. There is nothing misleading about that, on the contrary. Equally Casino does not overstate earnings in their reports: any other accounting treatment would be inconsistent with accounting rules. Selective use of time periods for cash, debt and EBITDA, ignoring the earnings improvement in the second half of this year, some double counting in debt, some omissions of value creation all lead to an erroneous SOTP. We see nothing in this report to make us unduly worried about the investment thesis of Casino.

In our view in complex situations, "following the money" and looking at cash generation, is a fail safe way of evaluating a company. Despite the Brazilian recession, despite the big investments they made in France, this company is generating 15% FCF yield (proportionally consolidated, an approach Muddy Waters will surely appreciate) and 7% dividend yield

PM

hmm

BE

Personally, dunno. I guess Block raises some valid concerns about an overly complicated business.

11:28 am
BE

But if "overly complicated" becomes a reason alone to short, we'll be losing a lot of interesting companies.

BE

Credit Suisse comes to a similar conclusion. No smoking guns.

BE

■ A material decline on no new information: In response to a large number
of client calls, we have reviewed our assumptions and analysis in light of a
report published by a well-known short seller. We reiterate our Outperform
rating and €55 target price.
■ It's still all about France: Our valuation for Casino's French operations is
€7.7bn, as detailed in our initiation report (p.47). This valuation represents
our view on the turnaround story within France, in particular the improving
LfLs and potential for improving margins. This contrasts with value of €3.9bn
stated in the short-seller's report which uses a multiple of Casino's trough
LTM EBITDA, in a period of significant price investments. We think using
EV/Sales multiples for each banner is a better methodology, as we believe
some banners were loss-making in the period. The difference is €33/share.
■ Conservative calculation of debt: We calculate parent company net debt at
€7.5bn, which includes the reported net debt, adjustments for cash within the
subsidiaries and other debt securities that rating agencies classify as equity.
This contrasts with the report's €9.4bn of debt. The difference is €17/share.
■ Subsidiaries valued at market value: Although we have research coverage
on four of the five subsidiaries, we decided to use market valuations to
maintain focus on the French operations. We updated the market value of
those subsidiaries in our report on Wednesday to €5.1bn, compared to the
report's valuation of €4.5bn. The difference is €5/shr.
■ Off balance sheet items: We currently do not incorporate the mark-to-
market losses of Casino's total return swaps. Losses (or gains) would only be
realised on settlement, but given the volatility of the underlying shares we
believe a heightened sensitivity to these instruments is warranted.

11:30 am
BE

I guess we need to separate the two claims here. Casino might well be "overvalued and misunderstood", in MW's words.

BE

It might also be disguising a deteriorating core business to sustain unsustainable debt by fudging the numbers. But there's not enough evidence of that to suggest we have a Noble-type sit here.

BE

We lower our target from €56 to €46 as we now only include a future return
on cash investment into new/ developing companies in our bull case. The
actual value of the portfolio changes by just 2% (mainly FX and a weaker
outlook for Westwing). This approach reflects a shift in strategy towards
greater financial focus (and investment) in large, established companies and
acquisitions. Despite a impressive track record (3x ROI), we believe this
approach dilutes the likelihood that the "platform" will generate sufficient
value in the coming 12 months, especially as more challenging externalities
(eg. FX, macro, funding) limits investors' risk appetite. Our target implies 59%
basic upside.
After a volatile and noisy 2015, we expect Rocket's complex investment case to
somewhat simplify in 2016 but it relies on 5 key drivers.

BE

1) For assets where growth is maturing (Home, GFG) we expect broad
profitability by 2017. Combined, we forecast €1.5bn revenues in 2016 with
scope to deliver 5-10% EBITDA margins by 2020. A re-acceleration of growth
at Westwing and, more importantly, Home24 is a key catalyst for 4q and, ex
Jabong, GFG continues to outperform our expectations, particularly on margin.
We value these assets at €8 per share.
2) Establishing market leadership that can be monetized and defended is
the key criteria for Rocket's faster growing businesses such as Lazada, where
we forecast GMV to close 2015 north of €1bn. Scale, longevity and unit
economics will determine valuations at future funding rounds. Growth has
consistently outperformed or expectations although funded by higher losses.
We value these assets at €21 per share.

BE

3) Controlling overall cash burn and accelerating the path to
profitability. Rocket is well funded with €1.7bn gross cash at the HoldCo
(€1.2bn net) with a further €1bn held at the op co levels. We expect significant
losses in 2015 where we forecast Rocket's cumulative share of €278m at the
Proven Winner level but expect this to reduce to €200m in 2016 and €64m in
2017. At the HoldCo level, management has guided to a €250-350m outflow
in 2016 and we expect this to reduce materially in 2017. Specifically we expect
funding rounds in 2016 for Lazada (€212m EBITDA loss in 9m15 vs €164m
cash),GFG (€225m, €140m); Jumia (€65m, €9.6m), Westwing (€46m, €15m).

11:35 am
BE

4) Delivering on 9 key Targets announced at the recent CMD on value
crystallization, investment (opex & capital), Transparency and the move to the
Prime Standard and "No significant M&A transactions." Rocket shares have
been particularly sensitive to newsflow related to capital raises, valuations and
weaker trading at several smaller businesses (eg. Lendico, EatFirst, FabFurnish
etc) but these are not material to the valuation.
5) Creating and scaling new businesses from the Berlin based platform
such as Carspring, Vendomo, Caterwings and Drivejoy. Deriving future value
from these assets as well as converting the promise of the "Emerging Stars"
such as TravelBird, traveloka and Helpling. Technically, this is the least
important driver in 2016.

BE

BE

We expect less volatility but a required catalyst is clear evidence of lower cash burn from 4q, in our view

BE

We have cut our estimates to reflect the more challenging trading environment which was confirmed in the Q3 trading update. We have reduced our PBT and EPS forecasts by 10% for 2015 and 16% for 2016. This assumes a further weakening in the last months of 2015 and a 2.7% organic sales decline in 2016, due to subdued end markets. However we expect sentiment to become progressively more positive during the year ahead. (1) The shares are trading on a discount to the sector on consensus forecasts based on low expectations. (2) Comparatives begin to soften from Q2 16. (3) Management execution remains strong and the sales mix continues to benefit from faster growth by higher margin Specialist Technologies. Furthermore (4) the strong balance sheet would support a cash return or M&A. The share price fall since June means there is upside to our target price of 635p (previously 785p). We move to Buy.

11:41 am
Bodycote PLC (BOY:LSE): Last: 562.50, up 23 (+4.26%), High: 583.50, Low: 557.50, Volume: 399.73k
undefined
BE

On miners, the sector note of the morning comes from UBS.

11:43 am
BE

Thoguh I don't think it changes any recommendations.

BE

Buy Glencore, BHP, Rio. Sest neutral. No sells.

BE

Is this the last of the commodity price downgrades?
Perhaps, but that does not mean it is the start of an upgrade cycle. The UBS commodity
team has published its Quarterly Price Review, materially cutting base metal and iron
ore prices in 2016-18. After a painful 4 year downgrade cycle, there are some signs
that we are approaching the trough such as: 1) price induced supply cuts; 2) capital
raisings; 3) increased restructuring. However, not all stakeholders believe in the new
lower demand outlook. Looking into 2016, we expect commodity prices to be volatile,
but believe the downside risk to spot is limited by further supply cuts while there is
potential for near-term upside from short covering. In our opinion, the probability of a
material acceleration in commodity demand driving a sustained recovery in prices in
2016 is fading and the process of supply rebalancing may take time to run its course.

11:44 am
BE

Where does this leave the European miners?
At spot commodity prices, the outlook for the mining sector is challenging with PE and
P/NPV valuations not compelling and FCF negative or struggling to cover dividends (for
those who are still paying them). However, we believe spot commodity prices are not
sustainable medium-term with large swathes of production cash negative and new
capex approvals limited. As a result, we see selective value medium-term for those
stocks with the right commodity mix. We favour commodities where supply is likely to
be constrained or contract in a low capex environment (copper, zinc & oil); our least
preferred commodities are those with structural problems in demand (thermal coal, iron
ore) or in supply (aluminium).

BE

Preferred European miners: Rio Tinto, Glencore, Boliden & BHP Billiton
For 2016 we focus on miners with low costs & strong balance sheets, including Rio
Tinto, Randgold & Hydro. We also like Glencore as it has positive stock specific catalysts
with divestments expected to reduce net debt materially over the next 6 months; it is
however vulnerable if base metals prices weaken further. Over the medium-term (2-3
years) we focus on stocks that offer leverage to the commodities with the highest
probability of a sustained price recovery. Here we believe the risk vs reward is most attractive for Glencore & Boliden (copper & zinc), BHP (oil & copper) and Fresnillo (silver/gold upside combined with significant volume growth).

BE

Forecasts are .... um ......

11:45 am

for Anglo; cuts to NPV range from -2% for BHP to -10% for Glencore.

11:51 am
BE

Here's the upshot of it.

BE

Oil majors face a structural dilemma. Diversification has fragmented upstream portfolios while increasingly companies are accepting lower returns in new riskier regions. These issues will be addressed through a combination of shrinking the upstream portfolio and acquiring more scale in high return regions. But, we think the strategic rationale of having a large position in a short-cycle basin in US shale is even more compelling today. The majors could go big for US shale in 2016.
Do we believe it? Yes. The credit market may be about to kick start the process It is true that valuation is a potential road block today but if the current tightening in credit markets are anything to go by, 2016 could be about to get very interesting from a shale M&A perspective.
We highlight Delaware and Midland basins in the Permian and the Bakken as core opportunities for majors given growth, scope for scale and fragmentation.

BE

A case study in 1998
Could majors go even bigger and kick start an M&A boom? In this report, we compare the 1998 M&A boom vs. today. We find that the key drivers of the 1998 boom: valuation, synergies in downstream and scale/growth in new geographies (West African and the Caspian) are not as compelling today. If deals were to happen today then we believe they would have to be focused on portfolio transformation.
Who are most likely to acquire from the European majors? Total, Statoil and BP
As we have discussed in previous research, post Shell-BG, we believe Total and BP have the biggest concerns that need to be addressed in their upstream portfolios as UK North Sea and West Africa struggle to remain competitive in a lower for longer oil price environment. Statoil will also need to continue diversifying from Norway though we recognise Johan Sverdrup buys them time.

BE

Interim results are, in our view, above the FY2016 run rate but we are not increasing our FY2016 forecasts. In this unpredictable autumn for weather, we will wait and see whether there is any disruption from snow in January and February, as there was in 2013. In the meantime, the stock, in our view, is significantly undervalued considering it has over 20% of its market value in cash, the potential for earnings growth of over 10% p.a. over the next three years and scope for further special dividends. We reiterate our BUY recommendation and our TP of 17.5p.

BE

Freddie George, of course.

11:55 am
BE

Results were better than expected.

Pre-tax profits increased by 10.1% to £588k vs. CFE Research £550k on sales up by
11% to £10.1m. Flooring LFLs increased by 3.1% while bed LFLs achieved double digit
growth from a relatively low base. The company opened three new stores, two of
which were relocations, leading to a net increase of one to 48 stores in the franchised
network. The company has since franchised five corporate stores leading to a
reduction in corporate stores to eight, which is perhaps the most encouraging news in
a positive statement. EPS rose by 45% to 0.6p helped by a decline in the tax charge
while net cash came in at £2.2m which is slightly ahead of our forecasts for FY2016.

The company is proposing a dividend of 0.125p while current trade is reported to be
positive. The company is hopeful of opening a further two stores during the rest of the
year and is considering the purchase of two freehold properties.

Risks to forecasts are now on the upside.
We are retaining our FY2016 pre-tax profit forecast of £1.3m (EPS: 1.28p) until we
have more visibility on the weather in the New Year. We are maintaining our
subsequent year forecasts.

Earnings are set to benefit from recent initiatives.

Results over the medium term are, we believe, set to benefit from recent initiatives
including the development of up to three stores each year, the conversion of up to
three corporate to franchise stores each year, the extension of the interest free credit
offer to all stores and a further strengthening of the bed ranges. In addition, results
should benefit from a ramping up in effort to digitally market to customers. The
valuation rightly takes account of the liquidity of the stock and the size of the
company. The discount, however, we believe, is too significant. The stock is broadly
rated at 9.2x, a discount of c.50% to its sector peers and Carpetright (CPR LN – HOLD
– TP 470p) on the basis of 2016 annualised earnings.
